stream_context.summary: Kaze spent most of the stream building and debugging several "star-select" menus. The main focus was a mine-cart themed screen for the Crystal Cave area; he fine-tuned fog, scrolling textures, spline movement and ensured the whole set-piece stayed inside the N64’s ±32 768 world-space limit to avoid crashes. He also reviewed new backgrounds from Biobak (Koopa Wave Cove/Carnival, Mouse Cave, Bubble Dome), talked about ROM-size optimisation for streamed music, and mentioned personal updates (moving house, new 3-D modelling job).

development_findings.summary: Arctic’s ‘strm64’ tool cut 1.7 MB of unused audio data (music that continued past loop points), freeing space for more streamed tracks.
development_findings.quote: Arctic realised his tool has some cool properties that allow us to save 1.7 megabytes of ROM space

development_findings.summary: Star-select backgrounds are static models plus one animated object (e.g. mine-cart) driven by spline math coded in C; Kaze uses fog and a grey plane to hide clipping and keep draw-calls low.
Objects positioned outside ±33 k coordinates crash real hardware; the mine-cart track had to be shortened and the camera/fog re-tuned to stay within the safe range.
development_findings.quote: If you render any object out of this range your N64 is just gonna crash

development_findings.summary: Switching the display-list microcode from plain F3D to F3DEX2 keeps displacement smaller and renders faster.
development_findings.quote: If you use regular F3D then the display list is a lot bigger than it should be and just renders a lot slower

development_findings.summary: Removed back-faces and hidden geometry on Koopa Carnival assets, saving ~80 triangles.
development_findings.quote: I'm just gonna remove these to save some... that saves 80 triangles

development_findings.summary: Disabled ‘nth color’ material flag on certain models because it makes them randomly vanish in some emulators.
development_findings.quote: The problem with having nth color set on emulator is sometimes they will just go invisible

development_findings.summary: Kaze prefers using s32 instead of bool in functions; on the R4300i it avoids masking operations and is ‘always better’.
development_findings.quote: A bool is typically just a single bit... an s32 is just always better and has all the same features

development_findings.summary: Long-term plan to move to ‘Katerinian’ per-object animations to cut down repeated coefficient loads.
development_findings.quote: As soon as we switch to Katerinian animations it's gonna be a lot less relevant

context_findings.summary: Kaze and Zeina move into a new house next week; Kaze also started a new government-related 3-D modelling job.
context_findings.quote: We're moving into our new house next week and I got a new job as a 3-D modeller for the government

context_findings.summary: Project funding is minimal: YouTube paid $6.90 last month; Patreon helps but he can’t offer a real salary to collaborators.
context_findings.quote: My YouTube channel last month, $6.90 and a little bit on Patreon. I definitely cannot pay him enough to buy all his groceries

context_findings.summary: Coding philosophy: variable casing is irrelevant because syntax highlighting already distinguishes functions/variables; strong opinions against style ‘rules’.
context_findings.quote: If anyone tells you you should do it a certain way they are 100 percent guaranteed a fucking idiot

context_findings.summary: Emotional self-portrait: ‘easily irritated’ on stream but quickly calms down.
context_findings.quote: I seem angrier than I am, I'm just very easily irritated, but I also like instantly just don't care anymore

biobak.summary: Delivered multiple star-select background models (Koopa Wave Cove/Carnival, Bubble Dome, Mouse Cave) and a mine-cart track with bird animation.
Flagged centring issues and requested minor layout tweaks (text alignment, fog, lighting).
biobak.quote: Move the text down a little, it's not centered

biobak.summary: Provides Yoshi sticker art and keeps a log of memorable Kaze quotes for merchandise.
biobak.quote: Every time you say dumb shit, Biobak has us covered

zeina.summary: Joined voice chat; brainstormed a Yoshi sticker pack and suggested using Kaze catch-phrases (‘I hate video games’).
Mentions social-media fatigue (Instagram feed now dominated by cat memes).
zeina.quote: My Instagram algorithm is ruined thanks to cats

key_stories.title: Audio-Space Breakthrough
key_stories.summary: ROM size was tight due to streamed music. Arctic discovered unused tail data after loop points and trimmed it, freeing 1.7 MB.
key_stories.challenge: Limited ROM space restricted how many high-quality streamed tracks could fit.
key_stories.process: Arctic inspected STRM files with his custom tool and cut everything past the loop marker.
key_stories.outcome: Extra memory headroom; team can now include more streamed music.
key_stories.key_quote: That saves a few megabytes here and there, which means we are allowed to have more streamed music than we thought.

key_stories.title: Mine-Cart Menu Crash
key_stories.summary: Initial mine-cart star-select prototype exceeded the N64’s coordinate range, causing potential hardware crashes. Kaze re-scaled and fog-masked the scene.
key_stories.challenge: The track was ~30 000+ units away, beyond hardware limits.
key_stories.process: Shrunk geometry, pulled camera back, inserted fog and a grey plane, recalculated spline math.
key_stories.outcome: Stable menu that still retains the cinematic mine-cart effect.
key_stories.key_quote: If you render any object out of this range your N64 is just gonna crash.

key_stories.title: Paying the Artist
key_stories.summary: Kaze realises Biobak’s workload deserves compensation but revenue is low.
key_stories.challenge: No formal budget for art despite extensive contributions.
key_stories.process: Kaze raises the topic on stream; promises to discuss payment privately.
key_stories.outcome: Open issue; compensation model still undecided.
key_stories.key_quote: We can talk about pay after the stream… you should be compensated somewhat.
